page.title: 05TREES IN THEDDINGWORTH
page.content: The trees on the wooded slopes at the north of our block are mixed, including some sweet chestnut felled about the time of the First World War, now grown up again from the stumps. During the 1970s and early 1980s Dutch Elm disease killed all the elm trees, which have been cleared away for firewood. Small plantations of mixed trees and one of larch have been planted to replace them. The remaining hedgerow trees are mainly ash with a few oak. Hedgerow fruits gathered locally are blackberries, crab apples, elderberries and hips. In the village there are 2 magnificent copper beeches, a Wellingtonia and horse chestnuts. In the Churchyard there is an avenue of yew trees and in the Chapel grounds an old deodar. An oak tree was planted in 1977 to commemorate the Queen's Jubilee.
